highlight: Strategists expect the ROE on the S&P 500 to expand slightly in 2024, driven by EBIT margins, since neither taxes nor interest expense should affect ROE this year. EBIT margins should benefit from faster cooling of inflation and unit labor costs.

thepixelchef/E+ via Getty Images Listen below or on the go on Apple Podcasts and Spotify Verizon impresses with wireless services, while 3M struggles on guidance. (0:15) Netflix snags the rights to WWE Raw. (3:33) Goldman Sachs picks its favorite return-on-equity growth stocks. (4:23) The following is an abridged transcript Our top story so far

In other news of note The Netflix (NFLX) news keeps coming. The streaming company announced that starting in January 2025, it will become the exclusive home of TKO Group's (TKO) WWE Raw in the U.S., Canada, U.K. and Latin America, with more countries added over time.

In addition, starting next year Netflix will become the home for all WWE shows and specials outside the U.S., including Smackdown, NXT and its premium live events such as WrestleMania, SummerSlam and the Royal Rumble. Since its inception in 1993, WWE Raw has been on linear television, most recently on Comcast's (CMCSA) USA Network.

Netflix also has an option to extend for an additional 10 years and opt out after the first five years of the deal. And in the Wall Street Research Corner Goldman Sachs shook up the constituents of its return-on equity growth basket, with some new additions.

New additions include Estee Lauder (EL), Kinder Morgan (KMI), Citigroup (C), Illumina (ILMN), Universal Health Services (UHS), Generac Holdings (GNRC), Broadridge Financial (BR), Jabil (JBL), Zebra Tech (ZBRA), IBM (IBM) and Dominion Energy (D).

Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) topped Q4 expectations thanks to the outperformance of its pharma and MedTech segments following the spinoff of its consumer care division Kenvue (KVUE). And RTX (RTX) shares bounced on earnings and revenue that came in ahead of forecasts.

TSLA +0,24% Adicionar/Remover de uma Carteira Investing.com – A Tesla (NASDAQ: ) deve reportar um lucro por ação (LPA) de cerca de US$ 0,70 no quarto trimestre, em linha com o consenso do mercado e as expectativas dos compradores.

Para o ano fiscal de 2024, a Evercore ISI espera um “tom mais cauteloso” na projeção da Tesla. A montadora deve registrar uma queda trimestral em unidades e margem bruta no primeiro trimestre, com um LPA estimado em cerca de US$ 0,60.
No entanto, os analistas são céticos quanto à possibilidade da Tesla atingir esse número sem uma pressão constante sobre os preços médios de venda.

A Tesla é vista como a mais frágil entre as 7 Magníficas, e a Evercore ISI prevê que ela continuará sofrendo revisões negativas de LPA, representando um risco de 15-20% para as estimativas de consenso para os anos de 2024 a 2026. Isso deve pressionar a ação, podendo gerar uma desvalorização de 10% na avaliação atual.

A Evercore ISI indica que US$ 160-180 é o patamar onde investidores de longo prazo preocupados com a avaliação podem considerar comprar a história do Modelo 2 de 2026 da Tesla. No fim da manhã desta terça-feira em Nova York, as ações da Tesla registravam alta de 2,04%, ao redor de US$ 213,05.
Ações da Tesla podem cair 10% com margem bruta menor, avalia Evercore ISI Por Investing.com

Steve Jobs & Steve Wozniak: The Apple Story An Unlikely Partnership The story of Apple Inc., one of the most iconic and influential tech companies in the world, begins with an unlikely partnership between two individuals who couldn’t have been more different in their backgrounds and personalities.

It was during this time that Wozniak designed the Apple I, a personal computer that would become the foundation of Apple Inc. Jobs recognized the potential of Wozniak’s creation and proposed that they start a company together.

In 1976, Apple Computer, Inc. was born, with Jobs as the visionary leader and Wozniak as the engineering genius behind their products. The partnership between Jobs and Wozniak was unconventional, with Jobs handling the business and marketing aspects while Wozniak focused on technical innovation. Their synergy, however, was undeniable.
Together, they launched the Apple II, a groundbreaking personal computer that would become a massive success and solidify Apple’s position in the tech industry.
The Birth of Apple The two Steves first crossed paths in the early 1970s when Jobs was in high school and Wozniak was attending the University of California, Berkeley.

It was during this time that Wozniak designed the Apple I, a personal computer that would become the foundation of Apple Inc. Jobs recognized the potential of Wozniak’s creation and proposed that they start a company together.

In 1976, Apple Computer, Inc. was born, with Jobs as the visionary leader and Wozniak as the engineering genius behind their products. The partnership between Jobs and Wozniak was unconventional, with Jobs handling the business and marketing aspects while Wozniak focused on technical innovation. Their synergy, however, was undeniable.

Together, they launched the Apple II, a groundbreaking personal computer that would become a massive success and solidify Apple’s position in the tech industry. The birth of Apple marked the beginning of a technological revolution.

Together, they complemented each other in a way that allowed Apple to innovate not only in technology but also in design and user experience. Despite occasional clashes and differing priorities, their shared commitment to their vision for Apple was unwavering.

Wrapping Up The stories of these five remarkable partnerships—Procter & Gamble, Microsoft, Apple, theSkimm, and Hewlett-Packard—reveal the surprising journeys that led to the creation of some of the world’s most influential companies.
